info.title: CoreCONNECT API V2
info.description:
The Sureify CoreCONNECT Edge API is a collection of OpenAPI-compliant endpoints that allow various business personas — including policyowners, agents, advisors, back office users, and home office users — to interact programmatically with a life insurance or annuity carrier. 
   
# Edge API Overview 
The following sections discuss fundamental principles shared across all Edge endpoints.   

## Client Compatibility
The Edge API is designed to be client-agnostic. Any system can use this set of endpoints to access life insurance carrier data (subject to authorization) and interact with business processes over that data.

Common clients include web applications, mobile native applications, hybrid/PWAs, and headless downstream service providers & distribution partners.

Sureify also offers two digital web applications built specifically against these Edge APIs: [LifetimeAGENT] (https://www.sureify.com/lifetimeagent/ ) and [LifetimeSERVICE] (https://www.sureify.com/lifetimeservice/).

## Authentication & Authorization

### Authentication
All CoreCONNECT Edge APIs require the requesting client to provide a valid Sureify access token obtained from the Sureify Identify Provider (IDP). 

The Sureify access token must be placed in the authorization header of every HTTP request. The Sureify access token is obtained via standard OAuth authorization flows.

Multiple flows are supported to meet the needs of various client types:
- *Frontend Clients* (e.g. web/browser/mobile)
  - Frontend clients acting on behalf of a logged-in user should use the Open ID Connect (OIDC) Code Authorization Grant Flow with Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE) to obtain an *ID token*, *access token*, and optional *refresh token*: 
    - The *ID token* provides basic information about the logged in user.
    - The *access token* must be included with all Edge API requests.
    - The *refresh token* enables the client to obtain new access tokens for some period of time without requiring the user to re-authenticate.
  - Since these types of tokens are associated with a logged-in user, the Edge APIs perform authorization on behalf of the user.  More details on authorization are provided in the sections below.
- *Backend Clients* (e.g. machine-to-machine requests)
  - Backend clients use the OAuth Client Credential Grant Flow to obtain an access token for making machine-to-machine API requests. 
  - Since these types of tokens are not associated with a user, the API authorization mechanism requires the requesting client to specify a user identifier for authorization. More details on authorization are provided in the sections below.

We also support federating with the carrier’s Identity Provider (IDP) to enable users to login to the Frontend Client with their own carrier credentials.

For carriers using LifetimeSERVICE and LifetimeAGENT Frontend Clients, Edge API authentication/authorization is handled automatically.

### Authorization
All CoreCONNECT Edge API responses include _only_ the data that is authorized to the requesting user.

However, as mentioned in the *Authentication section* above, the user associated with the API request is identified differently depending on whether the client making the API request is a Frontend Client or a Backend Client.

  - For Frontend Clients, the user’s identity is determined directly from the access token (as this token was obtained on behalf of the user via OIDC).

  - For Backend Clients, the user’s identity is provided via a header within the API request.
  
  > **NOTE**: 
    > Since Backend Clients can make requests on behalf of any user, it is critical that the credentials and tokens associated with these clients are protected and always kept secure within the carrier’s trusted infrastructure. 
  > 
  > Backend Clients are expected to be trusted machines that receive authenticated requests from Frontend Clients, then proxy the request, on the user’s behalf, to the CoreCONNECT Edge APIs.
  

Data returned from Edge API responses can further be filtered by various query parameters described in the *Filtering on Persona* and Filtering on Keycard* sections.

### Keycards
  Keycards are designed to provide access to a specific set of data, just as a physical building access keycard grants access to specific rooms. A keycard typically maps to a single agent/contract identifier, but can also map to a higher level agency or distribution partner such as an Independent Marketing Organization (IMO) or Brokerage General Agency (BGA).

When a keycard identifies a contract/agent, it provides access to the data authorized to that particular agent. 
When the keycard identifies an agency or distribution partner, it provides access to all the data authorized to that particular agency (which may include all downline data).

Users that have multiple agent/contract identifiers are authorized to use multiple keycards, which can be obtained from the [/keycards endpoint](#/paths/~1puddle~1keycards/get).

Users can also be authorized to access other users’ keycards. For example, a head producers might have access to the keycards of all agents in their agency. Likewise, home office users might have access to the keycards of all the agents for the entire carrier. See the section *Filtering on Keycard* for more information.

## Nulls and Representing Non-Existence 

We don’t send nulls in Read response bodies. For example: if an endpoint can return ten fields, but six of those fields hold null values, we will only send four fields in the response.

To represent non-existence of sub-objects within a collection (e.g. elements within an array) we respond with an empty collection (e.g. an empty array).

## Identifiers
We have two major types of identifiers in the Edge APIS:
  - Sureify IDs (property names use the suffix  _ID_)
  - Industry IDs (property names use the suffix  _Code_ or _Number_)

### Sureify IDs
Properties that include the suffix _ID_ (e.g. ID, policyID, agentID, documentID) refer to the unique solution-domain identifier that Sureify has assigned to each entity (whether that entity is a person, a company, a policy, etc).  We also use Sureify IDs to identify Workflow and Journey Instances.

We expose these Sureify IDs for the purpose of matching entities in our internal system to their corresponding records in external systems, such as carrier SORs.

> **NOTE**: Although the value of a Sureify ID MAY appear to be a UUID, you MUST accept values that are not UUIDs.

### Industry IDs
Properties that include the suffix _Number_ or _Code_  (e.g. policyNumber, carrierCode, accountNumber) refer to identifiers that are _already exposed_ to agents and policyowners as part of doing business in the Life and Annuity industry. 
These are identifiers that may show up on policy documents, commission statements, etc. such as a policy number, or agent employee ID number.

## Handling Change
Our Edge APIs will evolve over time. Future updates of this API may add new endpoints, parameters, or fields. In order to keep older clients working, the behavior and return values of APIs with given parameter values will not change without advance notice.

For example, you should not consider a Policy object invalid if it contains additional fields besides those currently documented below.

# About Downloads
Currently, we provide a single endpoint for downloading large objects (i.e. binary data such as pdfs). This endpoint is named [/puddle/documents/{documentID}](#/paths/~1puddle~1documents~1%7BdocumentID%7D/get).

We expect any future download endpoints to follow this same naming convention:  _/resourceName/{resourceNameID}_


# About Reads
Reads are GETs that return a complete array of structured data for a given type of resource (subject to the user’s authorization).

Read endpoints follow the naming pattern _/puddle/pluralnoun_, where the plural noun describes the type of resource being retrieved. For example, /puddle/policies retrieves all policy data that the requester has permission to view.

## Bulk Payloads 
CoreCONNECT rapidly responds with a bulk payload of all data the user is authorized to view. In some scenarios this may be a large amount of data (e.g. for agents who have access to a large downline book of business). It is important to consider this when architecting a client over these APIs.

Edge API responses can be further filtered based on various parameters described in the subsections below.

## Filtering Payloads
> **NOTE**: The parameters described in these sections ONLY filter the data the user is already authorized to view. 
> They will _never_ allow the user to see additional or unauthorized data.

### Filtering on Persona (REQUIRED)
Sureify currently distinguishes between two personas: agents and policyowners. The `persona` query parameter filters the API responses based on the desired persona. This becomes important in situations where a single logged in user has multiple personas (e.g. a person who is both an agent and a policy owner).

Policy servicing portals (like LifetimeSERVICE) make API requests with the `persona=policyowner` filter. This ensures that only the personal policies of the user are presented. Similarly, an agent portal (like LifetimeAGENT) makes API requests with the `persona=agent` filter.

### Filtering on Keycard (OPTIONAL)
By default, the Edge APIs return the data associated with all the keycards that the user is authorized to use. However, implementors have the option to use the `keycard` query parameter to filter response data by a single keycard. We do not support the ability to filter by multiple keycards at the same time.

Filtering on a single keycard enables clients to implement an experience similar to impersonation, allowing a head producer or home office user to selectively view the data associated with just a single downline agent. Likewise, it enables clients to implement an experience that allows users to view data associated with only one of their agent/contract identifiers.

## Snapshots Data Elements  
The Read Edge APIs include data structures called 'Snapshots'. These structures are named according to the pattern *elementSnapshot* (e.g. `productSnapshot`, `policySnapshot`, etc). 

Snapshots represent the state of a particular data element (e.g. a product, a contact, a policy etc) at a particular moment in time. Snapshots always have exactly the same data schema as the endpoint they correspond to.

For example, a `productSnapshot` has exactly the same schema as the `/products` endpoint. The difference is that a `productSnapshot` represents a particular product at a particular moment in time, while the /products endpoint returns an array of current products.

Snapshots ensure schema consistency, even when dealing with historical data that was not designed to fit into the present-day schema.

For example, a historical life insurance product that is no longer sold might be referenced on a policy. There are values for the productName and productCode. However, values for many other fields include present-day products (e.g. product type, linked documents, attributes) simply do not exist in this historical product record. Therefore, we only populate the fields in `productSnapshot` that we have data for. In this case, that means populating the productName and productCode fields with the values we have and leaving the rest empty. By providing the entire schema of the `products` endpoint to every snapshot, we give carriers the option to retain any historical values they like, while providing normalized data structures across our APIs.

Below is a complete list of data elements exposed as snapshots in our Read Edge API: 

**<u>Snapshot Data Elements List</u>**

- `productSnapshot` (/cases & /policies endpoints)
- `policySnapshot` (/commissions endpoint)
- `payee` (/commissions & /commissionStatements endpoints)
- `writingAgent` (/commissions endpoint)
- `client` (/commissions endpoint)
- `proposedClient` (/quotes endpoint)

get.description:
Requests a collection of applications for insurance products.

Includes the latest and historical answers for every question, along with the parent question text, modification timestamp, and role of the user who updated the answers.

Requests a collection of new business cases (i.e. pending policies). 

A case begins as new application and remains designated as a case until it either becomes an inforce policy or closes (without becoming a policy).  Each case moves through a number of different stages including application, underwriting, approval, etc.

Requests a collection of commission transactions and other line-item compensation transactions.

For commission statements (i.e. the PDF for a particular collection of commissions transactions) see the [Commission Statements endpoint](#/paths/~1puddle~1commissionStatements/get).

Requests a collection of commission statements (i.e. PDF statement documents). 

 For line-item commission transactions, use the [Commissions & Other Compensation Transactions endpoint](#/paths/~1puddle~1commissions/get).

Requests the contact information for a collection of contacts (i.e. persons, companies, and/or trusts). 

 Contact information includes the contact's name, address, email, phone number, website, etc.

Requests a collection of document references (i.e.  metadata for a document such as title, date, etc.). 
 
 To download an individual document see the [Document Downloader endpoint](#/paths/~1puddle~1documents~1%7BdocumentID%7D/get).

Downloads a document.

The [content type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Type) of the response and the document requested will match.

Requests a collection of financial activity line-items. 

 Each line-item represents a monetary value change on a policy (either a change in monetary amount or rate) that occurred at a particular moment in time. 

Together, these line-items can be used to reconstruct the history of financial activity on a given policy.

Requests a collection of fund allocation line-items. 

 These line-items show how new premium should be distributed across different investment options. Additionally, each line-item may include a total fund account value.

Requests the collection of keycards that the user is authorized to use. 

Keycards grant a user access to a particular set of records, in accordance with the carrier's access hierarchy rules.

Requests a collection of notes on cases and policies. 

Notes are miscellaneous messages that are added to a case or policy at a particular moment in time.
Requests a collection of payment methods (e.g. debit/credit cards, checks, electronic funds transfer information).
Requests a collection of policies (i.e. the life insurance contracts that a carrier and policyowner have agreed to).
Requests a collection of products and product types.
Requests a collection of qualifications (i.e. certificates, licenses, etc.) held by the current user. Only applicable to users who are agents.

Requests a collection of completed quotes and illustrations (i.e. cost estimates for a policy). 

This endpoint returns quotes and illustrations that were created in an external system, then stored in CoreCONNECT. This endpoint does NOT allow for the creation of new quotes.

Requests a collection of requirements. 

A requirement is a task that must be completed in order for a case/application to become an active policy (e.g. completing a medical examination).

Requests a collection of data for people or organizations listed on a policy, structured by the role that person or organization plays. Examples of roles include, but are not limited to: insured, annuitant, owner, and beneficiary.
Requests a collection of riders (i.e. additional benefits or coverages) applied to a policy.

Requests a collection of user profiles applicable to the current user. 

Profile information includes the user's contact information (e.g. name, phone number, address), as well as the contact information for any agencies the user is affiliated with.

> ## NOTE: ALPHA Endpoint  
> ### This endpoint is experimental and subject to change.

Requests the collection of users and party bindings that the logged-in user is authorized to view. 

A user is an individual or entity that uses a single set of login credentials to authenticate to a CoreCONNECT client such as LifetimeAGENT or LifetimeSERVICE. In this way, a user is a unit of authorization.

A single user is bound to one or more parties. Party bindings grant a user access to a particular set of records, in accordance with the carrier's access hierarchy rules.

post.description:

> ### This endpoint is experimental and subject to change.

Requests the collection of resources that match the search query provided by the user.

Requests the collection of users and linked parties that match the search query provided by the user.

schema.description: The name of the field to sort on.

userID.name: userID
userID.description:
Specifies the user identity for authorization when using backend/machine-to-machine (M2M) authentication. **REQUIRED when using an M2M token. DISALLOWED otherwise**. For more information, see [Authentication & Authorization](#authentication-authorization). 

Frontend clients do not need to provide a value for this header, since the user's identity is already embedded in the access token.

persona.name: persona
persona.description: Allows callers to filter the returned data set by `persona`. If a user has multiple personas (e.g. a user who has both a _policyowner_ persona and an _agent_ persona), this parameter filters the response such that the call only returns data which the specified persona is authorized to access.

keycard.name: keycard
keycard.description: Allows callers to filter the returned dataset by `keycard`. If a user is authorized to use multiple keycards (e.g. a user with multiple agent identities, or a home office user), this parameter filters the response such that the call only returns data which the specified keycard is authorized to access.

documentID.name: documentID
documentID.description: A unique identifier for the document being requested for download.

sortOrder.name: sortOrder
sortOrder.description: The order in which the search results are sorted (e.g. ascending or descending).

page.name: page
page.description: The page number for each page of results returned, used for pagination when multiple pages of results exist. If only one page of results exists, the value of this field is equal to 1. (1-based index).

pageSize.name: pageSize
pageSize.description: The number of search results returned per page. Use `all` (bulk search) to return __all__ the records matching the search criteria in a streaming response. When pageSize='all' is sent an error will be returned if you use sorting, pagination, or aggregations.

Persona.description: The role of the person accessing the API. This parameter specifies whether the person is the policyowner or the agent.

ID.description:
Correlation ID - A unique identifier for each entity (whether that entity is a person, a company, a policy, etc). 
We expose this ID for the purpose of matching entities in our internal system to their corresponding records in external systems, such as carrier SORs.
*While this value MAY appear to be a UUID, you MUST accept values that are not UUIDs.*
Also used for Workflow and Journey Instance IDs.

QuestionGroup.title: Question Group
QuestionGroup.description:
A category-marker for a collection of questions that share similar content or subject matter.

Values of the `sequence` property are consecutive for questions belonging to the same `questionGroup`.

ID.description: A unique identifier for the question group.

title.description: The title of the question group (e.g. Basic Information).

ID.description: A unique identifier for this question.

parentID.description: A pointer to the `ID` field for for this question's parent question (i.e. the question which this question is nested below). Top level questions to not have a parent question.

groupID.description: A unique identifier for the question group that this question belongs to.

sequence.description:
A number indicating where this question appears on the application, relative to all other questions.

Note: Questions are NOT guaranteed to be returned in consecutive order.
You must use the value of `sequence` to order questions relative to each other.

DateTime.description:
A timestamp, as specified in [ISO 8601-2:2019 Extended Date/Time Format (EDTF)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#EDTF).
Use this type for properties that represent a moment-in-time when a specific action occurred (i.e. a date or a date as well as a time). 
Time zone designator OPTIONAL.
Month and Day MAY be a single digit value, if value is less than 10.

BaseRole.title: Other
BaseRole.description:
The fields that are included in every role, regardless of role type.
This schema is extended by other Roles.

role.description: The function that a person or entity plays in relation to the policy.

contactID.description: A pointer to the full contact record of the person, company, or trust listed on the policy.

policyID.description: A pointer to the policy record on which this person, company, or trust is listed.

Duration.description:
An amount of time specified in [ISO 8601:2004 
(Duration)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Durations).

Use this type for any properties that represent durations.

Insured.title: Insured
Insured.description: A role object for an Insured. This extends the base role schema.

designation.description: A designation indicating how this insured is covered (i.e. primary vs. joint). The insured's designation depends on the way that the policy is structured and has implications for how death benefits are distributed, should this insured die.

isPrimary.description: True indicates that this is the main insured for the policy (i.e. the person who has completed the majority of the application). Only relevant in for policies that list multiple insureds.

issueAge.description: The age of the insured at the time the policy was issued.

riskClass.description: The risk class (e.g. Preferred, Super Preferred, Substandard, etc.) at which this insured was approved.

tableRating.description: The table rating (e.g. Table A/1, Table B/2, Table C/3 etc) at which this insured was approved.

Annuitant.title: Annuitant
Annuitant.description: A role object for an Annuitant. The annuitant's role on an Annuity policy is analogous to the insured's role on a Life policy. This extends the base role schema.

designation.description: A designation indicating how this insured is covered (i.e. primary vs. joint). The insured's designation depends on the way that the policy is structured and has implications for how the proceeds of the policy are distributed, should this annuitant die.

isPrimary.description: True indicates that this is the main annuitant for the policy (i.e. the person who has completed the majority of the application). Only relevant for policies that list multiple annuitants.

issueAge.description: The age of the annuitant at the time the policy was issued.

NonNegativePercent.description: Percent value (disallows negative values). For example, 150 represents 150%, and 1 represents 1%.

BeneficiaryDesignation.description: A designation indicating the order in which the policyowner wants benefits to be distributed to this beneficiary (i.e. primary or contingent). Note that multiple beneficiaries can be designated as `primary`. Likewise, multiple beneficiaries can be designated as `contingent`.

insuredRelatedTo.description: The insured whom the beneficiary is related to (e.g. the primary insured vs. another insured).

relationship.description: The way in which the beneficiary is related to the insured (e.g. Spouse, Child, Cousin, etc.)

allocationPercentage.description: The percentage of the policy's proceeds (e.g. death benefit) that this beneficiary receives after the insured/annuitant passes.

type.description: The kind of entity that this beneficiary is (e.g. a Charity, Trust, Company, Person, etc.).

isIrrevocable.description: True indicates that, regardless of whether the insured/annuitant has died or not, this beneficiary must approve any changes to the policy, including beneficiary changes (i.e. the insured/annuitant is unable to remove this beneficiary from the policy, unless the beneficiary explicitly approves the change).

isPerStirpes.description: True indicates that if a named beneficiary dies before the insured/annuitant, the descendents of that named beneficiary receive the policy's proceeds (e.g. death benefit) rather than the descendents of the insured/annuitant.

isPerCapita.description: True indicates that every living beneficiary gets an equal share of the policy's proceeds (e.g. death benefit).

isPrimarySplit.description: True indicates that the policy's proceeds (e.g. death benefit) is split evenly across all primary beneficiaries.

isContingentSplit.description: True indicates that the policy's proceeds (e.g. death benefit) is split evenly across all contingent beneficiaries.

relationshipToInsured.description: The way in which the beneficiary is related to the insured/annuitant, and which insured/annuitant they're related to.

custodians.description: A collection of custodians for the beneficiary.

contactID.description: A pointer to the full contact record for this custodian.

relationshipToBeneficiary.description: The way in which this custodian is related to the beneficiary.

Beneficiary.title: Beneficiary
Beneficiary.description: A role object for a beneficiary. This extends the base role schema.

Owner.title: Owner
Owner.description: A role object for an Owner. This extends the base role schema.

isPrimary.description: True indicates that this is the main owner for the policy (i.e. the person who has completed the majority of the application). Only relevant in for policies that list multiple owners.

relation.description: The relationship between the owner and the insured/annuitant (e.g. Spouse, Child, Cousin, etc.).

Agent.title: Agent
Agent.description: A role object for an Agent. This extends the base role schema.

type.description: A label indicating how this agent engages with the policy (e.g. Writing Agent, Servicing Agent, etc.)

isPrimary.description: True indicates that this agent is the main point of contact for the policy. Oversees correspondence and activity on the policy.

commissionPercentageSplit.description: The proportion of commission assigned to this agent when multiple agents are associated with a policy.

Other.title: Other
Other.description: A role object for other role types. This extends the base role schema.

isPrimary.description:
True indicates that this person/organization is somehow more important than any other person/organization that plays the same role on a particular policy.
For example, isPrimary may indicate the main point of contact, or the person who is ultimately responsible for fulfilling a piece of work.
Note that this marker is only relevant when there are multiple people/organizations who play the same role on a particular policy.

AnswerHistory.title: Answer History
AnswerHistory.description: A collection of historical answers, grouped by the question that they are associated with.

questionID.description: A pointer to the question that this set of historical answers is associated with.

answers.description:
A collection of historical answers.
Note: Answers are not guaranteed to be returned in any particular order.
Use the `attempt` property to determine the chronological order of answers.

date.description: The date and time at which this answer was submitted.

attempt.description:
A number indicating the chronological order in which this answer was submitted.
The `attempt` value with the highest number is the most recent answer.

Note: Answers are NOT guaranteed to be returned in chronological order.
Use the value of the `attempt` property to chronologically order answers relative to each other.

roleSnapshot.description: A snapshot of the role best characterizing the individual who submitted this answer.

Application.title: Application
Application.description:
A collection of applications for insurance products.
Includes a set of historical answers for questions on a given application.

caseID.description: A pointer to the case that the answers are associated with.

answerHistory.description:
A collection of historical answers, grouped by the question they are associated with. 

Note: Answers are NOT guaranteed to be returned in consecutive order.
You must use the value of the `attempt` property to order answers relative to each other.

applicationNumber.description: A combination of letters and numbers that the e-apply vendor uses to uniquely identify an application in the application entry system.

URL.description: The URL (i.e. web address) of the external server, website, or application to which a user may be redirected.

currency.description: The ISO standard currency code for this monetary amount.

value.description: The value for a monetary amount in cents. Negative values are not allowed.

State.description: A geographical region within the United States (e.g. CA or TX). - Uses the ANSI INCITS 38:2009[R2019] standard.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this product.

productCode.description: A combination of letters and/or numbers that the carrier uses to uniquely identify the given product.

name.description: The name of the product (e.g. SureCo Whole 30, Term 20, SureCo Annuity Plus).

carrierCode.description: A combination of letters and/or numbers that the carrier uses to uniquely identify the company associated to the product.

documentIDs.description: A collection of pointers to the documents related to this product .

attributes.description: A collection of key:value pairs that give information about various characteristics of the product, such as where the product is available (e.g. Availability:All of USA), the age range that the product is designed for (e.g. Target Audience:Seniors 65+), or the benefits offered in the product (Liquidity:Free Partial Withdrawals).

name.description:
The key part of a product attribute key:value pair. 
 
 If referencing the key:value pair examples given in the `attributes` description, the key are: Availability, Target Audience, and Liquidity.

value.description:
The value part of a product attribute key-value pair. 
 
 If referencing the key:value pair examples given in the `attributes` description, the values are: All of USA, Seniors 65+, and Free Partial Withdrawals.

category.description: The name of the category to which this attribute belongs to.

plans.description: A collection of plans available within the product. Plans are particular configurations of benefits or requirements, providing fine-grained variations within a given product (e.g. specifying how many years money must stay invested before withdrawal).

name.description:
The name of the plan available within the product.
 
 For example, if the product is "Whole Life 5", plan names may be "Whole Life 5 Silver", "Whole Life 5 Gold", or "Whole Life 5 Platinum with LTC".

planCode.description: A combination of letters and/or numbers that the carrier uses to uniquely identify the plan available within the product (ABC01s28).

URLs.description: A collection of URLs that redirect the user to an external server, website, or application.

name.description: The name of the external server, website, or application to which this URL redirects the user (e.g. LifetimeACQUIRE). Note that this name is separable from any button text that may be used to present the URL on a UI.

URL.description: The URL (i.e. web address) of the external server, website, or application to which a user may be redirected.

states.description: A collection of states in which this product is applicable, valid, registered, etc.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this group/type .

name.description: The name of this group/type.

CasePolicyBase.description: This schema is extended by Case and Policy.
CasePolicyBase.title: Case / Policy Base

ID.description: A unique identifier for this case or policy.

annualPremium.description: The amount of money the insured _would pay_ if paying on an annual mode (i.e. paying once per year).

annualizedPremium.description: The _actual_ amount of money the insured pays over the course of a year. This amount is calculated by multiplying the mode (the number of payments an insured makes per year) by the modal premium (the amount of money included in each payment).

applicationType.description: The process by which the application for this case or policy was submitted.

carrier.description: The insurance company that issues the policy. _Note that this may be a subsidiary of a larger

commissionableAnnualizedPremium.description: The amount of money paid in premium that is used to calculate an agent's commission on the policy over the course of a year.

coveredUntilDate.description: The date on which policy coverage ends (i.e. the last day the insured is still  eligible to make a claim or receive a death benefit). Typically found with Term policies. If a `coveredUntilDate` is included on a permanent policy, it is usually set to 100 years after the date when the policy was issued.

deathBenefit.description:
The amount of money that is paid out to the beneficiary of a life or annuity insurance policy when the insured or annuitant dies. Typically used in Whole Life, Universal Life, or Annuities (as opposed to Term Life).  

`deathBenefit` may differ from `faceAmount` in that `deathBenefit` may change over time, while `faceAmount` stays the same over the lifetime of a policy. 

The value of `deathBenefit` often changes because adjustments (e.g. the accrual of interest) are made to it over the lifetime of the policy. 

In Annuities, if an annuitant dies before the full annuity has been paid out, the `deathBenefit` is paid out to beneficiaries.

documentIDs.description: A collection of pointers to the documents related to this policy. Examples of policy-related documents include, but are not limited to: anniversary statements and policy pages.

effectiveDate.description: The date on which the case becomes an active policy.

faceAmount.description:
The monetary amount of the death benefit at the time when the policy was issued. Typically used in Term Life (as opposed to Whole Life, Universal Life, or Annuities).  

The value of `faceAmount` at the time of policy issuance is the same as it is at the time of the claim, whereas the value of  `deathBenefit` may change over time.

excess.description: The portion of a commissionable annualized premium that an agent does _not_ receive full first year commission on. Note: `commissionableAnnualizedPremium` = `target` + `excess`.

carrierLastUpdated.description: The date on which the carrier last updated this policy.

guaranteedMinimumDeathBenefit.description: The lowest dollar amount that the contract guarantees will be paid out in the event of the insured's/annuitant's death.

modalPremium.description: The amount of money a policyowner pays in premium when they receive their bill. The frequency at which the policyowner receives their bill and pays a `modalPremium` is called the `paymentMode`.

nextPremiumDueDate.description: The date on which the next premium payment is due.

paymentMethod.description: The way in which the policyowner pays the premiums on their policy (e.g. via EFT, direct billing, credit card, etc). Sometimes referred to as billing method.

paymentMode.description: The frequency at which a policyowner is expected to pay the premium on their policy (e.g. Monthly, Quarterly, Semi-annually, or Annually). Note: The amount of money payable each time the policyowner receives their bill is the called the `modalPremium`.

policyNumber.description: A combination of letters and numbers that the carrier uses to uniquely identify the policy; sometimes referred to as a contract number. A given contract MAY have both a `caseNumber` and a `policyNumber`, especially if the transition from case to policy took place recently.

productSnapshot.description:
A snapshot of the base coverage product the policyowner purchases in order to create their policy.
Modifying coverages such as riders, plans, etc. can be added to this base product to build out a full policy.

premiumType.description: The way in which premium money is received into the policy or annuity (e.g. Initial, Unplanned, EFT).

isOwnerSignatureMissing.description: True indicates that the owner's signature is missing from the policy.

issueState.description: The state (geographical region within the United States) in which this case or policy was issued.

status.description: The status of the case or policy. Examples include, but are not limited to Pending, Approved, Issued, Inforce, Paid, Lapsed, etc.

statusCategory.description: A group of related statuses. May be used as a metric for reporting or data visualization.

statusDate.description: The most recent date on which the carrier updated the `status` of this case or policy.

target.description: The premium monetary amount that is applied to the agents first year commission rate. Note: `commissionableAnnualizedPremium` = `target` + `excess`.

tenThirtyFiveExchangeAmount.description: The amount of money that can be transferred from an existing policy into a new policy without any immediate tax consequences.

value.description: The value for this monetary amount in cents. Negative values are allowed.

name.description: The name of the funding company.

referenceNumber.description: The reference number associated with the policy at the funding company to be exchanged into this new policy.

requestedDate.description: The date on which the carrier sent out a notification requesting the funds.

receivedDate.description: The date on which the carrier received the funds from the funding company.

requestedAmount.description: The total money requested by the carrier.

receivedAmount.description: The total money received by the carrier from the funding company.

status.description: The status of the money (e.g. received, outstanding, etc.)

appliedRiskClass.description: The risk class (e.g. Preferred, Super Preferred, Substandard, etc.) that the agent/client submits on the application. Risk class is subject to change as a case moves through the underwriting process. This is why the original `appliedRiskClass`  may be different than the final `approvedRiskClass` that appears on the inforce policy. After a policy becomes inforce, the original `appliedRiskClass` is stored for reporting purposes.

approvedRiskClass.description: The risk class (e.g. Preferred, Super Preferred, Substandard, etc.) that the carrier approves, and that therefore appears on the policy once it is inforce. Risk class is subject to change as a case moves through the underwriting process. This is why the original `appliedRiskClass`  may be different than the final `approvedRiskClass` that appears on the inforce policy.

approvedTableRating.description: The table rating (e.g. Table A/1, Table B/2, Table C/3 etc) at which the insured was approved. When the insured is table-rated, they must pay an extra percentage on top of the standard premium.

balanceDue.description:
The amount of money that the insured currently owes on a pending policy. 
For example, the insured may have a balance due if their policy is accepted at a higher rate than what was originally quoted. In such a situation, the insured must pay the `balanceDue` in order to make the policy inforce.

cashReceived.description:
The amount of money the carrier receives along with the application (i.e. the money that a policyowner submits as part of the application).
Note: Any additional money due, that is not received with the application, is considered a `balanceDue`.

dateCashReceived.description: The date on which the money that came in with the application (`cashReceived`) was collected by the carrier.

applicationReceivedDate.description: The date the application was received.

applicationSignedDate.description: The date the application was signed.

caseNumber.description: A number assigned by an application system such as Firelight or LifetimeACQUIRE, used to identify the case. If the case becomes a policy, the `caseNumber` is stored temporarily until a policy number or contract number is received.

NIGO.description: A summary of NIGO (Not In Good Order) state.

isNIGO.description: True indicates that the case is in NIGO (Not In Good Order) state.

reason.description: The reason why the case is in NIGO (Not In Good Order) state.

category.description: The category of NIGO (Not In Good Order) applicable to this case. Examples include Agent, Client, Form etc.

beginDate.description: The date on which the case transitioned into NIGO (Not In Good Order) state.

endDate.description: The date on which the case transitioned out of NIGO (Not In Good Order) state.

underwritingType.description: The type of underwriting performed on this case before it can become an active policy. Examples include but are not limited to: Full, Instant Issue, Automated, etc.

fundingCompanies.description: A collection of companies that will fund the case in flight.

fullName.description: A person's full name, as represented in a single data field. Use `fullName` whenever name data is not broken down into first & last names. `fullName` may also be used for names of companies, trusts, and organizations.

BaseEmail.description: An email address (i.e. an electronic mailbox designation for exchanging messages over the internet).

emailAddress.description: The text of the email address.

Email.title: Email Address
Email.description: An email address (i.e. an electronic mailbox designation for exchanging messages over the internet)

isPrimary.description: True indicates that this email address has been designated as the best one to use for a particular contact. Within a collection of email addresses for a given contact, **exactly one** must be marked `isPrimary`.

type.description: The context in which this email address is used (e.g. work vs. personal email address).

BasePhoneNumber.description: A telephone number associated with a contact (e.g. a person or an organization).

PhoneNumber.title: Phone Number
PhoneNumber.description: A telephone number associated with a contact (e.g. a person or an organization).

isPrimary.description: True indicates that this phone number has been designated as the best one to use for a particular contact. Within a collection of phone numbers for a given contact, **exactly one** must be marked `isPrimary`.

type.description: The context in which this phone number is used (e.g. work vs. mobile).

BaseAddress.description: A government-recognized geographic location, often where people or organizations can receive mail.

address1.description: The first address field, typically containing a number/ street name combination.

address2.description: The second address field, typically containing an apartment or suite number.

address3.description: The third address field, typically only used for indicating 'Care Of' (C/O), or other notes.

country.description:
A two or three letter country code.
Uses the ISO 3166-1 standard.

postalCode.description: A zip/postal code in five digit or zip+4 format.

type.description: The context in which this address is used (e.g. work vs. home address).

Address.title: Address
Address.description: A government-recognized geographic location, often where people or organizations can receive mail.

isBadAddress.description: True indicates that this address is known to be unusable, either because mail was returned, or because address validation failed.

isPrimary.description: True indicates that this address has been designated as the best one to use for a particular contact. Within a collection of addresses for a given contact, **exactly one** must be marked `isPrimary`.

governmentIDNumber.description: A government-issued identification number used for taxation and/or or legal identification purposes (e.g. social security number).

DOB.description: This person's date of birth (DOB). The field may contain only a birth year if data for the person is incomplete.

sex.description: The legally recognized gender of the person, usually as assigned at birth.

emails.description: A collection of email addresses for this person.

phoneNumbers.description: A collection of telephone numbers by which this person can be reached.

addresses.description: A collection of addresses for this person.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this contact.

personNumber.description: A combination of letters and numbers that the carrier uses to uniquely identify the person.

companyID.description: A pointer to the full contact record for the company or organization that this person is associated with (e.g. the LLC or sole proprietorship that this person does business under).

agencyID.description: A pointer to the full contact record of the business that this person works for.

name.description: The name of the corporate entity.

addresses.description: A collection of addresses for this person.

website.description: The URL for a company's website.

companyCode.description: A combination of letters and numbers that the carrier uses to uniquely identify this company or agency.

businessType.description: The legal business structure of this company (e.g. LLC, S corporation, sole proprietorship, etc.).

phoneNumbers.description: A collection of telephone numbers by which this company can be reached.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this contact.

parentCompanyID.description: A pointer to the parent company that this company is a subsidiary of (if one exists).

date.description: The date on which the carrier received the most recent payment.

amount.description: The amount of money the carrier collected at the time of the most recent payment.

reason.description:
An explanation for why the most recent payment differs from the normal (i.e. expected) amount. This field is only used in situations that significantly stray from the norm. 

 Example: if the most recent payment is twice as large as normal, the `reason` might be "This payment is double because the previous payment was skipped".

Percent.description: Percent value (allows negative values). For example: 150 represents 150%, 1 represents 1%, and -1 represents -1%.

CashValueHistoryItem.description: A line-item capturing the cash value of this policy at a particular moment in time.

value.description: The cash value of the policy at a particular moment in time (`date`).

percentageChange.description: The percentage rise or fall of cash-value during the time period

date.description: The date on which this cash value line-item was generated.

accountNumber.description: The "master" or "parent" contract number under which this policy is grouped. Only use this field when this policy belongs to a collection of policies that are all billed to a single "master" account (e.g. if someone holds a collection of policies, one for each of their grandchildren, each individual policy will be linked to the same master `accountNumber`).

accruedInterest.description: The total amount of money that has accumulated in interest over the lifetime of the policy

cashValue.description: The total amount of money that a policyowner can take out of their policy/annuity (i.e. the current monetary value of the policy/annuity, after any fees associated with withdrawal have been taken out).

isCollateralOwnershipAssigned.description: True indicates that there is a loan against the policy (i.e. the policyowner has used the policy as collateral in order to secure a loan). If the insured dies before the loan is repaid, the lender can collect the outstanding balance from the death benefit of the life insurance policy.

currentInterestRate.description: The interest rate that the policy currently pays at, as a percentage. This value may change over time.

paidThroughDate.description: The date through which the policy is paid for (i.e. the date on which a new premium will be due).

mortalityPaidThroughDate.description: A date recalculated by the carrier on a month-by-month basis that indicates whether the policy has enough cash value and/or premium applied to pay the cost-of-insurance into the next month. Some carriers may use this field to indicate when a policy is valid into the next month.

currentPlanLapseDate.description: The date on which a policy is expected to lapse if a policyowner continues to make monthly premium payments that _fall short_ of the monthly cost of insurance. In such situations the remaining monthly cost is deducted from the policy's `cashValue`, leading the policy to lapse once that cash value is depleted. This `currentPlanLapseDate` is only provided when the client is making partial premium payments.

noPremiumLapseDate.description: The date on which a policy is expected to lapse if the policyowner has _completely stopped paying premiums on the policy_, and is instead using the policy's `cashValue` to pay the policy's premiums. This `noPremiumLapseDate` is only provided when the client has stopped making premium payments.

deathBenefitOption.description: The name of a particular set of stipulations for the death benefit, or the way in which the death benefit on the policy is configured.

isDeathClaim.description: True indicates that there is currently a death claim against the policy.

isDeficientOrDelinquent.description: True indicates that the policyowner has made a payment which falls short of the full amount due (deficient), has failed to make a payment (delinquent), or both.

isDisabilityClaim.description: True indicates that there is currently an active disability claim against the policy.

repayBalance.description: The total amount of money required to pay off the loan, should the policyowner repay the loan today. This amount _excludes_ any expected/future interest.

mostRecentPayment.description: The most recent loan payment received by the carrier.

accruedInterest.description: The interest that has accrued on the loan. _Note- the carrier must choose the time period applicable to this interest rate (i.e. whether this field represent the interest accrued over the loan's lifetime, since the last payment date,  or over another period of time)_.

currentBalance.description: The current balance of the loan (i.e. the balance that remains at this moment in time, taking into account any payments that have already been made).

interestRate.description: The rate at which interest on the loan accrues.

lastDateToPayPremium.description: The hard deadline (often after a grace period has passed) by which the policyowner must pay the premium. If the policyowner fails to pay the premium on or before this date, the policy will lapse out.

mostRecentPayment.description: The most recent premium payment received by the carrier.

nonCommissionablePolicyFee.description: A non commissionable policy fee is the amount of money that is included in the premium that goes to cover the application processing costs. This fee is not commissioned to the Agent.

isModifiedEndowmentContract.description: True indicates that this is a Modified Endowment Contract (i.e. a life insurance policy that has permanently lost its tax benefits because it contains too much cash). When the `cashValue` of a policy exceeds federal tax limits, the IRS relabels the policy as a Modified Endowment Contract (MEC), removing tax benefits for withdrawals and loans.

nextDraftDate.description: The date the policyowner has chosen for funds to be electronically withdrawn from their bank account in order to pay the policy's premium. Only applicable when the `paymentMethod` for the policy is electronic funds transfer (EFT). _Note that this is different from they day on which the premium is due, or the `paidThroughDate`._

oldPolicyNumber.description: The former policy number for this policy. If this policy was transferred over, or otherwise originated from a previous policy with a different policy number, the original policy number can be stored here.

policyAge.description: The length of time the policy has been inforce.

policyFee.description: A policy fee is the amount of money that is included in the premium that goes to cover the application processing costs.

premiumToKeepPolicyActive.description: The amount of money necessary, as a premium, to keep the policy inforce. Typically seen on Cash Value policies.

baseCoveragePremium.description: The premium needed to keep the base policy inforce minus any of the rider coverages that have been added to the policy.

surrenderCharge.description: The amount of money that is charged in penalties, should the policyowner cancel the policy in order to withdraw money early/before an agreed upon date. `surrenderCharge` is typically calculated as a percentage, and varies from state to state.

surrenderValue.description: The amount of money that a policyowner would be able to withdraw, should they cancel the policy early/before an agreed upon date. _Note that `surrenderValue` = `cashValue` - `surrenderCharge`._

termConversionDate.description: The last day to convert a term policy into a permanent policy. Often referred to as the term conversion expiration date.

totalPremiumPaid.description: The total amount of money paid in premium over the lifetime of the policy.

totalWithdrawals.description: The total amount of money ever withdrawn from the policy. Differs from `yearToDateWithdrawals` in that this value is cumulative over the lifetime of the policy.

cashValueDate.description: The "as of" date for when the current `cashValue` was calculated by the carrier.

cashValueHistory.description: A collection of line-items of the account's total cash value at different points in time.

isSuspendIndicator.description: True indicates that the policy is Suspended.

Annuity.title: Annuity
Annuity.description: Extends Policy such that fields exclusively related to Annuities are added.

annuityValue.description: The amount of money of the annuity is currently worth.

costBasisAmount.description:
The original amount of money put into the annuity. 

Note: this value can be recalculated for various reasons (e.g. adding more money to the `annuityValue` on an anniversary may cause the value of `costBasisAmount` to be recalculated).

cumulativePremiumAmount.description: The total premium paid into this annuity over time.

currentValue.description: The total amount of money in the annuity, including any interest received over time.

excludableAmount.description: The amount of annuity payment that can be excluded from taxes using the annuitant’s exclusion allowance.

guaranteedMinimumInterestRate.description: The lowest interest rate that can be applied to the annuity. Also referred to as the "floor" interest rate.

grossDistributionAmount.description: The full amount of money to be distributed from the annuity, before any fees and/or taxes have been taken out.

guaranteedWithdrawalBenefit.description: The amount of money that the contract guarantees can be withdrawn over a particular period of time.

marketValueAdjustment.description: A fee that can be applied in the event of an early withdrawal that violates contract terms.

minimumDistribution.description: The minimum dollar amount that the annuitant/insured is required to withdraw during the payout period.

payoutSchedule.description: An assortment of data representing how annuity payments and withdrawals occur over time.

numberOfPaymentsExpected.description: The total number of times the annuitant/insured is expected to receive a payout.

method.description: The method by which payouts are transferred to the annuitant/insured (e.g. via EFT, check, etc.).

installmentAmount.description: The dollar amount paid out to the annuitant/insured in a given installment. The frequency at which this `installmentAmount` is disbursed is noted in the `frequency` property.

startDate.description: The date on which payouts from the policy/annuity began.

nextDate.description: The next date on which a payout will be made.

mostRecentDate.description: The most recent date on which a payout was made.

frequency.description: The frequency at which money is paid out to the annuitant/insured (e.g. Monthly, Quarterly, Semi-annually, or Annually).

type.description: The way in which installments are scheduled to be paid out to the annuitant/insured (e.g. systematic withdrawals, required minimum distribution payments, a one-time withdrawal, etc).

purchaseDate.description: The date on which the annuity was bought or purchased by the policyowner. Sometimes referred to as "signed date", because it is when the policyowner signs the paperwork agreeing to make the purchase.

qualificationType.description: A category indicating how taxes may or may not be applied to the contract once it is inforce (e.g. Qualified, Not Qualified, IRA, Roth IRA, etc).

yearToDateWithdrawals.description: The total amount of money that has been withdrawn from the policy or annuity since the beginning of the current year. This value is sometimes important for policyowner tax purposes.

currentYearContributions.description: The total amount of money paid into the policy/annuity since the beginning of the current year.

previousYearContributions.description: The total amount of money paid into the policy/annuity during the calendar year prior to this one.

yearEndInterestRate.description: The interest rate at which the policy is contractually obligated to pay for the duration of a calendar year. Note that this calendar year ends on the `yearEndInterestRateDate`.

yearEndInterestRateDate.description: The date on which the calendar year duration for a particular `yearEndInterestRate` ends.

Life.title: Life
Life.description: Extends Policy such that fields exclusively related to Life are added.

costOfInsurance.description: The amount of money required to keep the policy active/inforce, per billing cycle (i.e. the portion of the `modalPremium` that pays for the policy to stay inforce, as opposed to fees, etc).

modalFactor.description: A percentage that the insurance carrier uses to determine the premium to be paid when the mode is something other than Annual.  It is an increase of the overall premium by a modalFactor percent to cover the costs associated with the increased premium frequency.

specifiedAmount.description: The value of the death benefit, as written on the application when the policy was purchased. `specifiedAmount` remains constant regardless of how the actual value of `deathBenefit` may change over time.

target.description: The premium amount that is applied to the agents first year commission rate. Any premium that is not considered `target` but is paid by the insured is considered `excess`.

termDuration.description: The length of time for which a Term policy remains valid. Only applies to Term business. Typically this duration is reported in years (e.g. the Term policy may be valid for 10 years, 15 years, 20 years).

ID.description: A unique identifier for an individual commission transaction.

statementDate.description:
The date on which the commissions statement containing this transaction was issued. 

Many transactions can be rolled into a single statement, which is why `statementDate` may be different than `transactionDate`.

totalCheckAmount.description: The sum total of all transactions included on the commissions statement that this commission transaction is part of.

comment.description: A field to store additional information needed to explain something about the individual commissions transaction. The carrier can choose how they would like to delineate between this field and `description`.

description.description: A second field to store additional information needed to explain something about the individual commissions transaction. The carrier can choose how they would like to delineate between this field and `comment`.

reasonForCommission.description:
The basis or reason why this commission came to exist (i.e. the way in which the commission was calculated). Sometimes referred to as "commission type". 
 
 For example, if the commission is calculated from a rider's premium, the value of this field is "Rider".

transactionType.description:
The method of exchange taking place between the agent and the insurance company involved in this commission transaction.

```Credit```, ```Manual Activity```, ```Premium Payment``` and ```Trails``` are transaction types where the insurance company transfers money to the agent. These transactions have a positive `amount` value.

```ChargeBack``` , ```Clawback```, and ```Debits``` are ways in which the insurance company reclaims money from the agent. These transactions have a negative `amount` value.

transactionDate.description:
The date on which the carrier recorded this commission transaction in their system of record. 
 
 This date may be different from the `processedDate`, which is when the payee receives (or, for a negative `amount`, is requested to pay) the money exchanged in this commission transaction.

processedDate.description:
The date on which the carrier gathers together, processes, and generates statement(s) for the group of transactions that this transaction is part of. 
 
This date may be different than the `transactionDate` because the carrier may not pay the agent on the same day that the commission is recorded in the carrier's system of record.

amount.description:
The total amount of money the `payee` receives for this commission transaction (as opposed to the `totalCheckAmount` on the statement). 
This dollar amount is usually positive, but can be negative (e.g. for clawbacks or charge backs).

percentageSplit.description:
The portion of the overall commission `amount` that the `payee` receives, as a percentage. 
For example, if the `payee` on this commission transaction receives 40% of the commission, this value will be 40.
If there is only one writing agent on the case, this value is 100.

payee.description: The agent or company who is getting paid on this commission.

writingAgent.description: The original writing agent on the case associated with this commission.

client.description: The client of the policy associated with this commission.

carrier.description: The name of the insurance company that is involved in this commission transaction.

isFirstYear.description:
True indicates that this is a first-year commission (i.e. this commission transaction is taking place during the first year of policy). 
False indicates that this commission transaction is for a renewal year.

premiumAmount.description: The amount of money paid in the premium that was used to calculate this commission (i.e. the same premium that was used to determine the `commissionType`).

premiumDueDate.description: The due date for the premium which this commission transaction is based on.

monthsPaidFor.description:
The number of months that the `premiumAmount` pays for. 

  This value may not align with the `mode`. For example, the policy may be a monthly mode but the insured
may have made 2 monthly payments combined into a single transaction. In this case, the `mode` would be monthly but the `monthsPaidAmount` would represent two months worth of premium money.

mode.description: The frequency at which the policyowner is be expected to pay the premium on the policy associated with this commission statement (e.g. Monthly, Quarterly, Semi-annually, or Annually).

rateToBePaid.description: The percentage used to calculate the commission `amount`.

paidThroughDate.description: The date through which the policy is paid for (i.e. the date on which a new premium will be due).

firstYearCommissionAmount.description: The portion of this commission transaction `amount` that can be attributed to first year commission.

renewalCommissionAmount.description: The portion of this commission transaction `amount` that can be attributed to a renewal year commission. This value is often much less than the `firstYearCommissionAmount`.

trailCommissionAmount.description: The portion of this commission transaction `amount` that can be attributed to trail commissions.

feesApplied.description: The non-commissionable fees that are removed from the overall commission before paying the `payee`.

uplineRate.description:
The percentage used to calculate the money paid to an agent or agency that is "upline" from the `payee` (i.e. the person above the `payee` in an agent hierarchy). May also known as an "override" percentage. 
This rate may be a percentage of a premium, of the `payee`'s commission, or of something else.

uplineCommission.description: The amount of money paid to an agent or agency that is "upline" from the `payee` (i.e. the person above the `payee` in an agent hierarchy). May also known as an "override" amount.

totalPaidCommission.description: A running total for the amount of money paid in commissions to the `payee` associated with this transaction, over the lifetime of a the policy this transaction is associated with.

totalYTDCommissionPaid.description: The total year-to-date commission paid to the agent receiving this statement.

totalYTDFirstYearCommissionPaid.description: A running total for the amount of money made in commissions for this `payee` since the beginning of the year, during the first year of the policy this transaction is associated with.

totalYTDRenewalCommissionPaid.description: A running total for the amount of money made in commissions for this `payee` since the beginning of the year, during a renewal year (i.e. any year besides the first year of the policy).

policySnapshot.description: A snapshot of the policy associated with the commission transaction.

status.description: The status of the commission transaction

documentID.description: A unique identifier for the PDF version of this statement.

date.description: The date that the statement was issued.

payee.description: The person or company receiving (for a positive `amount`) or requested to pay (for a negative `amount`) the money accounted for in this commission statement.

amount.description: The total amount of money that is either deposited into the `payee`'s bank account (in the case of a positive value) or requested from the `payee` (in the case of a negative value) as a result of this commission statement.

name.description: The legal name of the trust.

establishedDate.description: The date that the trust came into existence as a legally recognized entity.

addresses.description: A collection of addresses for this person.

governmentIDNumber.description: A government-issued identification number used for taxation and/or or legal identification purposes (e.g. social security number).

isIrrevocable.description: True indicates that this trust cannot be modified after it is created without the explicit consent of its beneficiaries.

Trust.title: Trust
Trust.description: A legal entity that allows the policy owner to grant named third-parties (trustees) the right to manage assets on behalf of a beneficiary. Trusts are often used when beneficiaries on a policy are minors.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this contact.

trusteeIDs.description: A collection of the full contact records for the people and/or organizations legally responsible for managing the trust and its assets.

items.description: A unique identifier for a full contact record for a trustee.

grantorContactID.description: A pointer to the full contact record of the individual or legal entity (such as a company or organization) that establishes the trust and transfers assets into it. The grantor defines the terms under which the trust operates.

finalBeneficiaryContactID.description: A pointer to the full contact record of the individual or legal entity (such as a company, nonprofit, or organization) that ultimately receives the remaining assets of the trust once all trust obligations are fulfilled.

name.description: The legal name of the estate.

executorContactID.description: A pointer to the full contact record of the executor who is designated to manage the estate after the policyowner's passing

governmentIDNumber.description: A government-issued identification number used for taxation and/or or legal identification purposes (e.g. tax identification number).

addresses.description: A collection of addresses for this person.

Estate.title: Estate
Estate.description: The legal entity designated to receive assets from a policy when no specific beneficiaries are named or surviving. The proceeds are distributed according to the policyowner’s will or applicable estate laws.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this contact.

name.description: The legal name of the charity.

addresses.description: A collection of addresses for this charity.

isGovernedByBoardOfDirectors.description: True indicates that this charity is being governed by a board of directors (a group of individuals) who are responsible for overseeing the charity's operations, ensuring compliance with legal requirements, and making strategic decisions.

Charity.title: Charity
Charity.description: A legal entity, typically non-profit, designated to receive donations, resources, or assets which are subsequently utilized to advance the charity's mission, in strict accordance with relevant laws and regulations.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this contact.

Document.title: Document
Document.description: The metadata used to identify this document.

ID.description: A unique identifier for the document.

title.description: A short phrase explaining the purpose of the document, or what the document is used for.

documentNumber.description: A combination of letters and numbers that the carrier uses to uniquely identify the given document.

categoryIDs.description: A collection of unique identifiers for the categories to which this document belongs to.

filename.description: The name of the file as seen by the user, should they download the file. Includes a file extension.

carrier.description: The name of the insurance carrier that supplies this document (may be a subsidiary within a larger carrier).

carrierLastUpdated.description: The timestamp indicating when the document was last updated by the carrier.

states.description: The states in which this document is applicable, valid, registered, etc.

versionID.description: A unique identifier for a given form version .

isOrderable.description: True indicates that the user can order the hard copy of the document.

isArchived.description: True indicates that the document is archived. False indicates active.

editionDate.description: The month and year this edition of the document was published.

DocumentCategory.title: Document Category
DocumentCategory.description: The category under which a document falls. Categories are arranged in a hierarchical tree structure with parent categories and sub-categories.

ID.description: A unique identifier for the category to which this document belongs to.

parentID.description: A unique identifier for the parent category of this category (i.e. the category that this category is nested beneath).

name.description: The name of the category a document belongs to. This can be a high level category or a sub-category.

description.description: A short phrase explaining the purpose of the document category, or what the category is used for.

FinancialActivity.description: A line-item value change on a policy. Examples include, but are not limited to: premium payments, cash value changes, and changes in interest rate.

date.description: The date on which this financial activity occurred.

rate.description:
The rate that changed on the `date` of this  activity. 

This field is only applicable if this financial activity is for a rate change. Examples include, but are not limited to: interest rates.

name.description:
The name of the activity (i.e. shorthand to explain why a value on the policy changed). 

 Examples include, but are not limited to: Initial premium, EFT premium, Feature change, Guaranteed minimum interest rate, etc.).

amount.description:
The monetary value change that occurred on the `date` of this  activity. 

This field stores the actual monetary value change for any activity that is NOT a rate change. Examples of financial activities resulting in `amount` changes include, but are not limited to: loan repayments, annual fees, premium payments, etc. 

Note: When the financial activity is a premium payment, the value of `amount` is the equal to the value of `premiumAmount`.

grossAmount.description: The total `amount` for the activity _before_ the removal of any deductions, fees etc.

netAmount.description: The total `amount` _after_ the removal of any deductions, fees, etc.

premium.description:
The amount of money being paid as premium on the policy, on the `date` of this financial activity. 

 Note: this field does NOT represent the monetary value change for this financial activity -- that value is stored in the `amount` field. However, when the financial activity is a premium payment, the value of this field is equal to the value of `amount`.

mode.description: The frequency at which the policyowner pays the `premium` on the policy (e.g. monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, etc.).

policyID.description: A pointer to the case and/or policy that this financial activity is associated with.

paymentMethodID.description: A pointer to the payment method that this financial activity is associated with.

status.description: The payment status of the transaction. Examples include, but are not limited to paid, success, failed, processing.

policyID.description: A pointer to the case and/or policy that the funds are associated with.

name.description: The name of the fund (i.e. the name used when marketing the fund).

disclaimer.description:
The legalese that accompanies a given fund, meant to protect the business entity administering the
fund against any unwanted claims or liability.
disclaimer.example: These are products of S&P Dow Jones Indices, LLC, a division of S&P Global, or its affiliates ("SPDJI") and has been licensed for use by SureCo. Standard & Poor's® and S&P® are registered trademarks of Standard & Poor's Financial Services LLC, a division of S&P Global ("S&P"); Dow Jones® is a registered trademark of Dow Jones Trademark Holdings LLC ("Dow Jones")

amount.description: The total amount of money tied to an individual fund.

allocationPercent.description: The percentage of new money being paid into the policy that should be invested in this fund, NOT a historical purchasing percentage.

allocationDate.description: The date on which the amount of money allocated to this fund was last updated in the carrier's system of record.

rate.description: The interest rate of the fund during the time period covered by the crediting strategy.

rateDate.description: The date on which the rate of this fund was last updated in the carrier's system of record.

Capability.description: A capability that this user is authorized to.

Keycard.description: A tool used to grant a user the ability to access a set of records.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this keycard.

contactID.description: A pointer to the full contact record of the person or organization to which this keycard is assigned.

keycardNumber.description: A combination of letters and numbers that the carrier uses to uniquely identify this keycard.

name.description: The name of the person or organization to which this keycard is assigned. For organizations, use the `fullName` option.

ownerType.description: The type of the keycard owner.

capabilities.description: A collection of permissions that this keycard is authorized to.

carrier.description: The carrier that the keycard is affiliated with.

ID.description: A unique identifier for the note.

policyID.description: A pointer to the case and/or policy that this note is associated with.

author.description: The person who wrote the note `content` and attached the `Note` to the case or policy.

name.description: The name of the author.

contactID.description: A pointer to the full contact record for the author.

noteAddedDate.description: The date or timestamp when the `Note` was written or modified.

content.description: The text that makes up the body of the `Note`.
content.example: This application was received via paper and was missing signatures.  It has been returned for completion.

isPrivate.description: True indicates that this note is only visible to the author.

isEditable.description: True indicates that this note was created in a client built against the CoreCONNECT platform, such as a web application (e.g. LifetimeSERVICE or LifetimeAGENT), mobile application, etc.

CreditCard.description: A credit or debit card that is used to make payments.

processingNetwork.description: The name of the company responsible for processing any transactions that are made with this credit or debit card (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, American Express, etc.)

cardNumber.description: A masked version of the credit or debit card number. Used to identify the card.

expirationDate.description: The day on which this credit/debit card can no longer be used.

accountHolderName.description: The name of the person or organization who owns this credit/debit card. If this credit/debit card belongs to an organization, use the `fullName` option.

address.description: The address that is used for billing with this credit/debit card.

BankAccountNumber.description: The account number for a bank account.

BankAccount.description: A bank account or check (i.e. a small document that orders a bank to pay a specified amount of money to a payee).

accountHolderName.description: The name of the person or organization to whom this bank account or check belongs. If this bank account belongs to an organization, use the `fullName` option.

bankName.description: The name of the bank where the bank account is held.

type.description: The kind of bank account this is (i.e. checking or savings).

routingNumber.description: The routing number for this bank account.

AutopaySetup.description:
The information that is needed to set up automatically recurring payments, separate from the `formOfPayment` itself. 
 
 Missing values indicate that automatically recurring payments are not enabled for this `formOfPayment`.

dayOfMonth.description: The day of the month on which each automatically recurring payment is processed.

amountOption.description:
The automatic payment option chosen by the payer. Dictates how much money is sent in each automatically recurring payment.
 | Enum | Amount of money sent in each payment |
 |--------------------------|----------------------------|
 | `custom` | An arbitrary amount (set by the payer) |
 | `minimum` | The lowest possible amount required to keep the account in good standing |
 | `balance`  | The amount owed at the time of payment |

amount.description: The amount of money sent in each automatically recurring payment. This field is only used when the payer has `amountOption` set to  `custom`.

PaymentMethod.description: A way in which someone pays for a service, policy, or product (e.g a credit card, debit card, or check).

ID.description: A unique identifier for this payment method.

paymentForm.description:
different types of payment forms.
'creditcard' - a credit card payment form.

isDefault.description: True indicates that this payment method is automatically used for a given policy, unless issues arise, or unless the payor specifies an alternative payment method to be used for a particular transaction.
